column1: #FORMAT=WebAnno TSV 3.2
#T_SP=webanno.custom.Referent|entity|infstat
#T_RL=webanno.custom.Coref|type|BT_webanno.custom.Referent
#Text=Prevent a Computer from Waking Up from External Devices
#Text=If you 've experienced your computer suddenly turning itself on after you 've put it to sleep or you 've just shut it down , you may need to investigate what ’s causing it to wake up .
#Text=The common causes that wake up your computer are hardware devices and scheduled tasks set to wake up the computer .
#Text=You might not even know that this has been happening especially if you have closed the lid of your laptop and did n't notice the lights blinking again .
#Text=Steps
#Text=Determining the Possible Causes for the Wake Up
#Text=Access the Command Prompt .
#Text=Click on the Start menu and look for the Command Prompt application .
#Text=This is usually found under the Accessories folder .
#Text=Click on it to launch it , and a window with a DOS-like environment will be opened .
#Text=Check the last wake trigger .
#Text=On the Command Prompt , type in “ powercfg – lastwake ” and then press the Enter key .
#Text=The Wake History details will be displayed .
#Text=If the Wake History Count is more than 0 , that means your computer was woken up by something .
#Text=Note the wake source .
#Text=If the Wake History Count is not 0 , the Wake Source details will also be displayed .
#Text=The Wake Source will state what caused your computer to wake up .
#Text=For example , if a device attached to a USB port was the source , USB Root Hub will be displayed .
#Text=Preventing Devices from Waking Up
#Text=the Computer
#Text=Access the Command Prompt .
#Text=Check devices .
#Text=To see the list of hardware devices that can wake up your computer , type in “ powercfg -devicequery wake_armed ” on the Command Prompt and then press the Enter key .
#Text=The list of hardware devices will be displayed .
#Text=Some possible devices that can wake your computer include , but is not limited to , your keyboard and your mouse .
#Text=Note the devices .
#Text=Take note of the list of hardware devices that can wake up your computer .
#Text=You will need to configure them properly in the Device Manager .
#Text=Open the Control Panel .
#Text=Click on the Start menu and click on “ Control Panel . ”
#Text=The Control Panel applets will be displayed .
#Text=Open the Device Manager .
#Text=Browse through the items under the Control Panel and look for “ Device Manager . ”
#Text=Click on it .
#Text=The Device Manager will be opened and the list of hardware devices for your computer will be displayed .
#Text=Look for the devices .
#Text=Navigate through the Device Manager until you find the possible devices that may cause your computer to wake up .
#Text=Click on the triangle icon beside each device to expand the category .
#Text=Open the Device Properties .
#Text=Right-click on the device you want .
#Text=Select “ Properties ” from the menu to bring out the device ’s properties .
#Text=Disable Wake Up property .
#Text=From the Device Properties window , select the Power Management tab .
#Text=Untick “ Allow this device to wake up the computer ” option .
#Text=Click “ OK ” to save your changes and exit .
#Text=The selected device will no longer wake up the computer .
#Text=Disable all other devices ’ wake up properties .
#Text=Repeat Steps 6 to 8 to disable all possible devices that can wake up your computer .
#Text=If left enabled , sudden or accidental movements that affect these devices can wake up your computer .
#Text=Preventing Tasks from Waking Up the Computer
#Text=Open Command Prompt .
#Text=Check wake timers from tasks .
#Text=To see the list of scheduled tasks that have set wake timers , type in “ powercfg – wake timers ” on the Command Prompt and then press the Enter key .
#Text=The list of scheduled tasks will be displayed .
#Text=Wake timers
#Text=wake up your computer at the defined time for it to run the scheduled tasks .
#Text=This can be useful if you want to run certain tasks on schedule , even without you monitoring them .
#Text=Note the tasks .
#Text=Take note of the list of scheduled tasks that can wake up your computer .
#Text=Uninstall programs or adjust schedules .
#Text=From the list of scheduled tasks , check which ones you really need .
#Text=Uninstall or remove the ones you do n’t need , and adjust the schedules for the ones you do .
#Text=Set a schedule that ’s good for you and your computer .
#Text=Adjusting the scheduled tasks can be done from the Windows task scheduler or directly from each of the programs .
#Text=Disabling Wake Timers
#Text=Open Control Panel .
#Text=Click on the Start menu and click on “ Control Panel . ”
#Text=The Control Panel applets will be displayed .
#Text=Open “ Power Options . ”
#Text=Browse through the items under the Control Panel and look for “ Power Options . ”
#Text=Click on it .
#Text=The Power Options will be opened .
#Text=Change the plan settings .
#Text=Your computer ’s power plans will be displayed .
#Text=Click on the “ Change plan settings ” link beside the power plan you ’d like to modify .
#Text=Change advanced power settings .
#Text=Look for the “ Change advanced power settings ” link and click on it .
#Text=The Advanced settings for the Power Options will be displayed .
#Text=Disable wake timers .
#Text=Navigate through the list of settings until you find “ Sleep . ”
#Text=Click on it to expand its properties .
#Text=Under Sleep , click on “ Allow wake timers ” to expand it further .
#Text=Set both properties under it to Disable .
#Text=No wake timers will now be able to wake up your computer .
